snippet: In the first year of a California program that ties academic performance to financial rewards for public schools and educators, two-thirds of the state's public schools showed improvement on tests that provide the basis of the program, officials a...
lead_paragraph: In the first year of a California program that ties academic performance to financial rewards for public schools and educators, two-thirds of the state's public schools showed improvement on tests that provide the basis of the program, officials announced today. Seventy-one percent of the 6,815 schools eligible to participate met their targets, and 67 percent of those are now in line for about $660 million in awards.
abstract: California education officials report two-thirds of public schools showed improvement in program that ties performance on standardized test to financial rewards for schools and educators and are in line for about $660 million in awards; Delaine Eastin, superintendent for public instruction, plays down cheating incidents at few schools; agrees performance index should be based on criteria beyond one test (M)

headline.main: School Improvements Are Cited in California
